docs.lead_paragraph: SEPTIME WEBRE, director of American Repertory Ballet, does not consider beheading to be a topic for casual discussion. But he has no problem with its role in ''Seven Silences of Salome,'' a ballet the company is bringing to Brentwood on Saturday. On June 1, Mr. Webre becomes artistic director of the Washington Ballet, which performs at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. As a parting gesture to the New Jersey-based American Repertory Ballet, he is taking it on a small East Coast tour with three dances he describes as a journey for the audience. The seven-man elaboration of Oscar Wilde's stage poem ''Salome'' is one.

headline.main: Goodbye to One Phase, Hello to the Next

docs.abstract: American Repertory Ballet director Septime Webre comments on upcoming performance of Seven Silences of Salome at Sagtikos Theater, Suffolk Community College, Brentwood, Long Island; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A side effect of the 47 percent drop in welfare rolls has been an increase in the number of low-income people who have lost their Medicaid and have no other health insurance. Almost everyone who leaves welfare for work is entitled to keep Medicaid, but studies show that some states have improperly discouraged people from seeking it. ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Private rooms in hospitals were once only for those affluent patients willing to pay as much as $300 a day extra for some peace from the chatter, beeping machines and groans coming from the next bed. Now a growing number of hospitals are eliminating shared rooms and offering all patients -- Medicare and Medicaid, rich and indigent -- their own rooms, often at no extra charge. The shift toward private rooms is largely a byproduct of the revolution wrought by managed care. Most hospitals are under pressure to compete for patients. Insurers used to pay hospitals based on a semiprivate room rate. Now they typically pay the same flat amount no matter what the type of room.

headline.main: Competition for Patients Spurs Some Hospitals Toward Providing Only Private Rooms

docs.abstract: Growing number of hospitals are elminating shared rooms and offering all patients--Medicare and Medicaid, rich and indigent--their own rooms, often at no extra charge; shift toward private rooms is byproduct of revolution wrought by managed care; most hospitals are under pressure to compete for patients; insurers now typically pay same flat amount no matter what type of room patient has; another factor is technology, as hospitals need more space for increasingly sophisticated life-support devices;independent study finds patients in private rooms recover faster; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Every patient in Britain knows about the notorious National Health Service waiting list, which tells how many people are waiting for hospital treatment for anything from varicose vein removal to hip replacement surgery. Never a short list, it currently boasts 1.12 million sick and generally tired members. Waiting has always been part and parcel of the British health service, a price patients pay -- sometimes willingly, sometimes grudgingly -- for free medical treatment. But there is another list, one that the Government, which has vowed to improve health care, does not officially acknowledge and that patients are just learning about. This is the underground waiting list -- the waiting list to get on the waiting list -- and it appears to be rising precipitously, even as the Labor Government proudly announces that the official list itself is shrinking.

headline.main: Britain's Prescription for Health Care: Take a Seat

docs.abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair's Labor Government pledged to devote large portion of extra $880 million it allocated to Britain's National Health Service toward reducing amount of time people must wait for various kinds of hospital treatment, from varicose vein removal to hip replacement surgery; but there is another waiting list, of people who cannot be put on official waiting list until they receive confirmation from two doctors of their need for treatment; existence of this underground waiting list of people waiting to get on official waiting list could undermine Labor's efforts to hasten medical treatment; many people must wait year and more to get apopintment with specialist; photo; graph (M)cialists who can

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Reconsidering Patients' Rights'' (editorial, April 10): Under our current health care system it is employers or the Government, not consumers, that choose our health care policies for us. Short of changing jobs, most of us do not have the choice to ''shop'' elsewhere for our health care.
docs.abstract: Letter by Dr D Ted Lewers, vice chairman of AMA, warns patients will not be protected if decisions about medical necessity are left to sole discretion of health plans; supports having independent doctor mediate such disputes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: State Assemblyman Thomas P. Di Napoli, who was elected chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party at a raucous but harmonious convention on Thursday night, today called on party workers to stay united and work for the defeat of Republicans in the fall. As his first official duty, Mr. DiNapoli joined former State Assemblywoman Barbara Patton, his nominee for co-commissioner of the County Board of Elections, for a round of meetings and courtesy calls.

headline.main: New Nassau Democratic Leader Seeks Party Unity

docs.abstract: Assemblyman Thomas P DiNapoli is elected chairman of Nassau County, New York, Democratic party; Stephen J Sabbeth resigned after conviction in bankruptcy fraud case (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Edmund M. Braun, a psychiatrist and labor advocate who worked to obtain better health care for the poor and Social Security coverage for physicians, died April 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 81. The cause was a heart attack, his son Carl said.

headline.main: Dr. Edmund Braun, 81, Health Advocate for Poor

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty-nine students ended an 11-hour sit-in at Fairfield University in Connecticut yesterday after the university made a modest concession to their demand that its 60 janitors be granted union recognition. On Thursday afternoon, the students, hauling sleeping bags, books and backpacks stuffed with food, marched into the main administration building, a hilltop mansion where the university president, the Rev. Aloysius P. Kelley, has his office. They began their sit-in just outside his office after giving him a letter asking him to make sure the janitors were unionized by May 1.

headline.main: Fairfield Students End Sit-In Backing Janitors

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Reconsidering Patients' Rights'' (editorial, April 10): The insurance companies spent more than $70 million to persuade Congress that they should not be held accountable if they fail to deliver what they promise. They refuse to concede that the question of what care is ''medically necessary'' should be based on what is best for patients rather than on what is best for insurance-company stockholders.
